intro: Vernonia gnaphalifolia, commonly known as blue mistflower, is a herbaceous perennial native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its fluffy, blue-gray inflorescences that resemble mist, which appear in late summer to early fall. The plant has lance-shaped, hairy leaves that are typically arranged oppositely along the stems. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained soil. Vernonia gnaphalifolia is often used in native plant gardens for its ornamental value and ability to attract pollinators.
